chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: A bridging reform would keep the Electoral College but modernize it so outcomes track broad voter support: replace winner‑take‑all with a uniform proportional method in every state and add an automatic runoff or ranked-choice option to ensure a majority winner. Pair this with a national baseline for voter access, chain-of-custody, recount triggers, and risk‑limiting audits, while leaving day‑to‑day administration to states. Phase changes in over multiple cycles with bipartisan oversight and clear legal guardrails so the rules are stable, transparent, and widely accepted.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Pursue an incremental reform that keeps states central to administering elections while reducing winner‑take‑all distortions so results better reflect the national electorate. Prioritize either proportional (or district-based) allocation of electors and/or a legally durable interstate popular‑vote compact, and consider ranked‑choice or runoff options to ensure majority support and reduce spoiler effects. Pair any structural change with clear, enforceable nationwide baseline standards for ballot access, counting, recounts, certification timelines, and routine post‑election audits under bipartisan/nonpartisan oversight to strengthen legitimacy and trust.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Reform the Electoral College in a way that preserves states’ constitutional role but makes outcomes track the national vote more closely: replace winner-take-all with proportional (or district-based) elector allocation and allow states to join an interstate popular-vote compact once it is legally vetted and transparent. Pair any structural change with clear national minimum standards for ballot access, counting, chain-of-custody security, routine risk‑limiting audits, and uniform recount/certification timelines so close elections are trusted. Consider optional ranked-choice or runoff mechanisms for president to ensure the winner has broad support, and phase reforms in over multiple cycles with bipartisan oversight.
